Shcridan's irouse and lobby were beset
with duns every morning, who were told
that Mr.. Sheridan was not yet up, and
shown into the several rooms on each side
of the entrance. AS soon as he had break

ed out very deliberately between them, to the

ways afraid to go to ask debt OF long
standing, lest he should borrow twice as
much. A play had been put off one night,
or favourite actor did not appear, and the
audience demanded to have their money
back again; but when they came to the door,
they were told by the check taker there was
none for them, for that Mr.. Sheridan had
been in the mean time and carried ofT all the
money in the till.

A letter from Granada contains the follow
ing account of most extraordinary and
horrible event, which has taken place IN
that ancient capital of the Moors On the
9th of December last, the Feast OF the Con-
ception. the church appertaining to con-
vent of nuns at Granada, was filled as usual
with the faithful at high mass. After the
ceremony the crowd dispersed, and the only
persons who fingered in the church were
two cavalry officers. They were also III
the act of returning, when nun, who had
remained behind the rest of the sisterhood,
made a sign to the officer who was follow
inc his comrade, that she wished to speak
to him. He accordingly told his comrade to
wait for him outside the church, and ne re-
turned to speak to the nun, when the follow


ing dialogue took place: "You are man OF
honor and discretion, presume, sir!'' yes
sister, am both the one and the other. =

seryicep" eyes, sister," 81 will not con-
ceal from you that the service ! require, at

extraordinary intrepidity: knowing this, are
YOU still willing to render me the service i
reouire9' "Yes. sister, I am determined.
"Vcry we'll, when you hear the convent bell
strike half-past twelve to nigh, be at such
gate, (particularizing the gate,) shall De az
the other side to open it, on your knockihg
twice, and you shall then learn what 1t IS
require Of you. win you be faithful to the :;
rendezvous." "Yes, sister, shall be there.


"Well, depend upon you; adieu." They
narted' and the officer quilted the church.

There's a language that's mute, there's a silence


that speaks,


There is something that cannot be told.
These are words that can only he read in the


checks,


And thoughts but the eye can unfold.
There's look so expressive SO kind,
So conscious so quick to impart,
Though DUN, in an instant it speaks ont the


mind,


And strikes in an instant the heart.
This eloquent silence, this converse Of soul,
In vain we attempt to suppress;
More prompt it appears from the wish 70 control,
More apt the fond truth to express.
And oh the delights in the features that shine,
The raptures the bosom that melt,
When best with each other this converse divine
Is smutually spoken and felt.
LOVES LANGUAGE.

MY UNCLE's WEDDING.


NV uncle was q man of other years: that is,
his habits of acting and thinking were all formed
in the old school. He lived twenty years with
ON old fashioned wife; and as they had been born
and brought up together, they got along very
well, and were as hearty, thriving, happy cou-
lie, as any that are to be found to this day IN
Annandae. But the good woman died at last;
and my uncle could not endure a life of single
blessedncss, as some callit; it was very wretch-
edness, to him. SO he married new wife, with
new notions, new fashions, and all the ct ceteras
of the modern school. He thought he did We
ry wise thing. And he tapped me on the shoul-
der, lust as we were setting down to the wed.
ding supper, eBob," said he, in half whisper,
"get married.; there is nothing like it" "Cer.
tanly, SIR" said I, for reverenced his COUNSEL
"but it you please I'll stand by ana look ou'
little longer" 49,,
| When the hustle and noise was over little,
went down to the Dale to spend the summer
with my uncle. The good dame had begun the
work of reformaton cunning as fox, she mad
broke ground gently at first. There was rich
new mirror, hung low in the parlour; bold en-
croachment, for the old gentlemen used always
to hold that looking glasses were only made to
shave by, and that nobody who don't wear
beard ever ought to look in one; accordingly his
own glass had hung chin high for quarter OF
century, and not one ofhis own children had ev-
er seen its own face until they knew the use OF


razor.


One after another of the old articles Of furni.


ture were displaced, and new carpets, chairs, Ia


bles, &C. &c. introduced by my good aunt; and


whenever her spouse evnced the slightest dis


position to be angry, she gave him geod natur-


cd chuck under the chin, and assured the dear
fellow that good wife was always mistress OF
her house and that she was determined to be


good wife and rule the roast in her own domi-


Gil I,esides; she taught my uncle that his hand.


some fortune entitled him to look little above


his neighbors; to claim that quality which should,


as much as possible, exclude the idea OF equall-
ity, vulgar doctrine that had long been Preva-


lent in the Dale. :.


NV good uncle Yielded inch after inch to his


worthy spouse, until the old house was fitted up
in great style, and a common farmer would haro-


" know where to set down his 6 eat clumsy foot
in it. She obtained over him wonderful ascen-
dency some how; for he got to be as doc'e as
lamb. Sometimes, it is true, he locked sorrow.


full, and sighed deeply, and took his broad
brimmed hat and cane, and trudged over the
; fields to neighbor Hodges to sit and smoke his
S nine again in an old oaken chair by the great


chimney-place, and when there, he seemed 10th
to go back again; but he loved peace, and always
r went home at tea time 49,


NV aunt was woman of talent. She did one
. thing at time she was to be successful in
, whatever she undertook, for she bent all her


mind to the single object. 1t is this singleness


of purpose that removes mountains. She mad


now set her house rights, as she called it, and
= from sundry hints and preparations, l began ere
, long to surmse that she intended setting her old
man to rights next.


There was very little of the dandy about my
{ uncle He wore great brmmed hat upon his
:. hale round hcad-a shad-bellied coat of greasy


green, with dark ivory buttons; q vest of genu-
IL ,y, p,I tnaVNr .ttNfrsg
] velvet small clothes, buckles, and very large
d Shoes and made very portly, venerable appear
: ance in the sun. Beside, he used spectacles and
: tobacco, and trod fiat upon his feet when he
S walked


S Nv aunt began her second campaign. She
. bought him wig and quizzing-glass, declaring
y that he looked about fifty years too old tor
d her in his old fashions-and she got them


on too. The old man little testy, but she
:, took him by the arm and brought his bald pate
: and spectacles before the mirror. At any rate


this was the argument she used. His tobacco
box went next NV uncle scolded-Iny aunt
i, = r,asonei-and she beat him in the argument
- though he argued that tobacco was necessary to


preserve his teeth, but she sent tor dentist,
. and had them plugged and scoured' TIL he tarly
- - cried for mercy, and assured .'ie ueht'st eiey
- would last forever.


Y Rut nv uncle's troubles did not end here
o The next time his good lady went to town she
e bought him new suit of bright blue CLOTH
il rhe coat and vest would not meet around him
y bv about eight inches; but my aunt gravely told
y him. her husband was not to look like a pudding
bag that the clothes were of perfectly gentcei
= shape and size, and they didn't lit him-that
n was all. So after bandying good many more
j. hard words than had been used in his house be-


fore she got six tbicknesscs Of flannel off him
and as he had grown in his way of dressing rath-


or too large, she fitted up set of her old stays,
- and compressed his rotundity few inches more
Is when the clothes went on buttoned. She had
l. a good deal Of sweetness in her disposition
S. however, and she assured him over and over, as


he sat gasping for breath beside her, that he
Is would grow quite genteel, and the clothes be
N come very easy, BY dieting little.


ie NV unclc's standing establishment still requir
ID ed alteration, however. The.good dame vowed
l. that at present in his new costume, he looked
= Just like turkey-that his great feet were 1

Unclouded-in the wide domain


Offancy, there is not a scene
Richer and lovelier than the reign
Of Spring and her gay world OF green
No vision purer than that blue


Broad sky, begirt with starry gems,
Just fading far from mortal view,


like fancy's visioncd diadems.
From burning through the voiceless night,
And lst'ning to the skyward song,
Drinking each others balmy light,


And holding still communion long
Go they at morn's first oricn; beam,
To some unknown mysterious cline,
With records Of each sinful dream


That stained the shaded brow Of time
But snlcss nature smiled abroad,


Through lofty Wales and winding rllls;
And the peac e-speaking voice of God,
Gladdcns the valleys and the hills
Nature in harmony speaks out


The bursting rapture which she feels.
And fragrant odours breathe about
Where'er the golden day beam steals.
And was there not human voice


To swell the song that choir began
No-graseful nature may rejoice,


And praise-but not ungrateiul man,
PQTTGYa
TIE SUNNY SPRING,

full articles.article:
ny him to the gate at which the nun was to
be. Accordingly at the appointed hour. the


two officers were at the gate, which, on the
concerted signal being given, was opened by
the nun. The chosen officer entered, and
the other remained close to the gate, to
watch the conclusion Of this extraordinary
adventure. The nun said to the officer who


entered, "you are man Of courage and hon
our, and are entitled to my warmcst graft


tude." The night being very dark, and the


passages through which they had to go OBJ
scure; the nun made him hold corner OF


her robe, and in this manner conducted him


to cell, where there was lamp alight.-
She made him sit down, and invited him to
take glass of liquor with her, at the same


time producing two bottles. She filled him


glass out of one, and took little herself out


of the other After he had emptied his


glass, she told him to go to one side of the
! bed while she placed herself at the other
! The officer obeycd-the nun then said we


are alone-my door is fastened-look"'--
and at the same moment she proceeded to
pull down the bed clothes. and discovered to
his great horror and amazemcnt, the dead


body Of monk, who had been poinarded


The nun then continued-"You must take
upon your shoulder this body, and carry it


outside the convent; will light you to the


gate of the first court. You must instantly


obey, or you are dead man; for, the first


motion you make, unless it be to take up the


body, | shall shoot you through the head =
and suiting the acton to the word, she drew
! pistol from her bosom, and presenting II
at him. 81 know, that my own life will be
. the forfeit if you refuse; for after shooting
, you, have another pistol for myself" The
officer seeing no other means OF escape, took
u, the body on his shoulders. and accompa'


MED by the nun, who carried dark lanthorn
+ proceeded to the gate by which he entered
, and, on issuing from it, threw down his hor-
rible burden at the feet of his comrace, whit
, was waiting to laugh with him, at what h'
= supposed was pious love intrigue. Ate
), rccounting to his friend the almost incredi
!. ble adventures in which he had been en-
! gagged, they both resolved to repair Instant.
. to the Corregidor, and inform him OF tn
, circumstances. They had proceeded scarcei,
!, hundred PAGES from the convent, when tn
=, officer who had brought out the body, sud
3 denly complained of the most excrutlatin
" and burning pains in the stomach he 500
: after tell upon the pavement, and in tey
- moments expired. His friend, beside him
!, self with terror, ran with the utmost spec
!" to knock up the Corregidor, and inform hin


of this tissue of terrors. Notwithstanding
y the exertions of the magistrates and police
4 no discovery has yet been made OF the de
. mon who perpetrated this double murder

ru ming down his face al Sheridan's jokes,
and almos, ready to hug him as an honest
fellow.


Shcridan's irouse and lobby were beset
with duns every morning, who were told
that Mr.. Sheridan was not yet up, and
shown into the several rooms on each side
of the entrance. AS soon as he had break
tasted, he asked. Are those doors shut,
John ? and being assured they were. march
ed out very deliberately between them, to the
astonishment of his scf-invited guests, who
soon found the bird had flown. / have heard
one of his old city friends declare, that such
was the effect of his frank, cordial manner,
and insinuating eloquence, that he was al
ways afraid to go to ask debt OF long
standing, lest he should borrow twice as
much. A play had been put off one night,
or favourite actor did not appear, and the
audience demanded to have their money
back again; but when they came to the door,
they were told by the check taker there was
none for them, for that Mr.. Sheridan had
been in the mean time and carried ofT all the
money in the till.

full articles.headline: LIFE IN SPAIN.
full articles.article:
A letter from Granada contains the follow
ing account of most extraordinary and
horrible event, which has taken place IN
that ancient capital of the Moors On the
9th of December last, the Feast OF the Con-
ception. the church appertaining to con-
vent of nuns at Granada, was filled as usual
with the faithful at high mass. After the
ceremony the crowd dispersed, and the only
persons who fingered in the church were
two cavalry officers. They were also III
the act of returning, when nun, who had
remained behind the rest of the sisterhood,
made a sign to the officer who was follow
inc his comrade, that she wished to speak
to him. He accordingly told his comrade to
wait for him outside the church, and ne re-
turned to speak to the nun, when the follow


ing dialogue took place: "You are man OF
honor and discretion, presume, sir!'' yes
sister, am both the one and the other. =
"Are you willing to render me an important
seryicep" eyes, sister," 81 will not con-
ceal from you that the service ! require, at
YOUR hands, requires not only discretion, but
extraordinary intrepidity: knowing this, are
YOU still willing to render me the service i
reouire9' "Yes. sister, I am determined.
"Vcry we'll, when you hear the convent bell
strike half-past twelve to nigh, be at such
gate, (particularizing the gate,) shall De az
the other side to open it, on your knockihg
twice, and you shall then learn what 1t IS
require Of you. win you be faithful to the :;
rendezvous." "Yes, sister, shall be there.


"Well, depend upon you; adieu." They
narted' and the officer quilted the church.
On reioining his comrade, he told him what
had taken place, and asked him # he should


keep the appointment. The other, on he .,
inc told that the nun was about 3o,and not Ill


formed. s advised him to keep the appointment
j I'D afE.rea for fear of accident, to accompa-

full articles.headline:
From the Lon. Monthly Mag.
MR.. SHERIDAN.
full articles.article:
TAYLOR, of the Opera House, used to say


OF Sheridan, that he could not pull on ms


hat to him in the street without 1t costing


him fifty pounds; and if he stopped to speak


to him it was hundred.


No one could be stronger instance


than he was, OF what is called 'hvlng


from hand to MOUTH He was always in


want of money, though he received vast sums
of which he must have disburscd; and yet
nobodv can tell what became Of them, for he
Maid nobody. lie spent his wife's fortune
fsi.teen hundred pounds) in six weeks
iaunt to Bath, and returned to town as poor
az a rat Whenever he and his son were
invited out into the country, they always
went in two post chaises and four !; he In
ooe and his son Ton following in another.
| This is the secret of those who live in round
of extrayarance, and are at the same time
always in debt and difliculty-they throw


away the money they get on any new ran
gled whim or project that comes III tneir
way. and never think Of old scores, which OF
course accumulate to a dreadful amount
Sheridan once wanted to take Mrs. oheriuan
a very handsome dress down into the country
and went to Barber & Nunn's to order 1t,
saving he must have it by such a day, OUT


promising they should have ready money
Mrs. Barber Il think it was) made answer
III h,t the time was short, but that ready mo-
ncy was very charming thing, ana that nc
should have it. Accordingly, at the time ap-
nointed she brought the dress, which came
to five and twenty pounds, and 1t was sent IN
"a Mr.. She, idan who sent out Mr. Grimm
ZONE of his iackalls) to say he admired It eX-
ceedinrly. and that he was sure Mrs Sherl-
dan would be delighted with it, but he was
sorry to have nothing under hundred
mound bank note in the house. She said she
had come prepared for such an accident
and could give change for hundred, two
hundred, or five hundred pound note, IT II
was necessary. Grimm then went back to
his principal for further instructions VINO
made an excuse that he had no stamped re-
ceipt by him. For this Mrs. b. said she was
also provided-she had brought one in he'
pocket. At each message, she could near
them laughing heartily in the next room al
the idea of having met with their match tor


once and presently after Sheridan came


out in high good humor, and paid her the a.


mount of her bill. in ten five and one pounds


Once when a creditor brought him oii


for payment, which had often been present


ed before, and the man complained OF IT.


soiled and tattered state, and said he wa


quite ashamed to see it. III tell you VIVA


I'd advise you to do with 1t my TREND, sait


Sheridan, take it home and write it upo'


harcAn,ent = He once mounted hors'


which horse dealer was showing Git nea


a coffee house at the bottom of st. James


street, rode it to Tattersal's and sold it, ant


walked quietly back to the spot from whenc


he set out. The owner was furious. he swor


he would be the death of him; and in a quar-


ter of an hour afterwards they were see


sitting together over a bottle of wine in tn
coffee. house, the horse. jockey with tear

the Duke of Buck ingham, who procured
makers. grinders, and polishers OF glass from
Venice, to settle in England.


"The printing of calicoes was first prac-
tsed in London, in 1876; and nearly at the
same time the weaver's loom was introduced
into the metropolis from Holland; and it was
called the Dutch-loom engine"


The great increase in the population and
domestic traffic of the metropolis, led to that
useful establishment, the tenny tost, which
was set up by one Murray, an upholster, in
The year 1858.


The year 1894 became most memorable
one in the commercial anals of the metropo-
lis; by the institution of the bank Of England,
which was Incorporated by charter on the
2eth of July; and the effects of which on the
trade, prosperity, revenues and government
of G. Britain, are incalculable.


"N1usiins of British manufacture were
first made in 1881, and they were sold in
London the same year"

full articles.headline:
rHE LADIES' FRIEND.

CONDITION OF WOMEN IN SOCIETY.


From late EngHsh poper.
full articles.article:
In the late Kaleidoscope, in reference to
!ar correspondent who has taken up the sub
lect Of the condition of women in society. the
editor adduced some historical facts in illus
ration Of the subject, from which we make
'he following extracts:


The portrait drawn by our fair cores
pondent may indeed be thought fair carica-
Wre. but that is point upon which we shall
uot at present offer an opinion, as we shall
eohhne ourselves to facts illustrative Of fe-
male condition in former days, with view
70 SHOW if the women of England at present
Ne treated by the men more like equals and
.s .sNlonai beings than formerly. the favorable
ssaange in their condition must be ascribcd
- an Improvement in the character of the

TERMS. y.-AnvEnTisEMENTs not exceeding
.ne souare will be inserted four times for one
Ia,l,r I% and 20 cents for each subsequent inser-
,;on If continued for three months, 81 5O-tor
sy months, 81 50; or for ono ycarS8.


nj Subscribers arc entitled to the privilege OF
having their names, place ofrcsidence, and occu-
nation, Inserted in the Register, Gratis.
TERMS or SUBSCRlPI1ON-To those
who receive this paper by mail, tro doHars' ana
nc.r Who do not, t,ro doilus nnd dtweniyfne cents
,Ye,r +, ApvAscE II not paid in advance, 50 SO
vii be charged; and if not paid before the expi-
ration of the year, 50.


'r1TNosu5scrption will be discontnuedunless
,vo o. weeks notice is given and all arrearage
nad

laws affecting the weaker sex; for we cannot
deny that what are now considered, by re-
snectable society, as the rights and privilc-
res of women, are but too often held in sui
ferapce. and may be withdrawn at the CAP
rice of the lords of creation.


But although married woman has tew'
if any. chartered rights, and is unques stiona-
bly dependant upon the will OF the husband,
we are of opinion that English wives II they
cannot lay claim to actual independence no
cnioy large share of virtual independence,
in consequence OF, and commensurate with
the progress Of civilization.


There has been a period when women
were not only deemed an inferior race, but
when doubts were entertained whetner they
belonged to human species. Ho'croit, IN Ills
travels through Holland, France, &c. INTRO
duces the following passagc-ot' i OK quotes
Gregory of Tours,to prove that at 'hc councli
of Macon, the question whether women were
or were not human beings, was hotly disput-
ed: and after much division Of sentiment, II
was at last solemnly declared in the council,
that women did not constitute par' OF the
human race"


| Lord Kaimcs, in his History OF Man, says,
"Women, by the laws of Ilindostan, are not
admitted to be witnesses, even IN civil
case; and blush (adds his lordshp) to ac-
knowledge that in Scotland the same writer
observes, that mot many centuries ago,
law was made in England prohibiting the
New Testament in England to be read by
women, apprentices, journeyman or serving
men" If we look back to the most polish
ed nations of antiquity, We shall tnd the
treatment of women such as we might DC
led to expcct from horde Of savages. They
we're considered as mere goods and chat
ties" and might be bequeathed by her hus
band. by will. to any new master.


The following passage, IN confirmation
the fact, may be found in Jones translation
of the speeches of IsGus:-"fet more,
husband might bequeath his wife (am"uGs
the Athenians) like part of his estate, I.
any man whom he chose for his succeaaor!'
and the mother of Demosthencs was actualt
left by will to Aphobus, with portion 9
eighty minas. The form of such beqoes
| is preserved in the speech of Isaus again
Stephanus, and runs thus: "This is tine las
will of Pasio, the Acharucan. I give IN
wife Archippe to Phornio, with fortune {
one talent in Peparrhethus. one talent
Attica, house worth one hundred mina
together with the female slaves, the orna
mcnt of gold, and whatever else may be
it.'


d, In Greece, women were not allowed TO 8
present at the Olympic Games. They SC
dom made their appearance in public, an
c never sat at table when strangers were pre-
ent. We have already ascribed the impro'
ed condition of women in modern times
the progress of civilization, which by brlnj
ing the sexes more frequently into each otl
- er's society has introduced habits OF polit
ness, which some accute writer has dehns
to be artificial good nature. What the La


in poet said of the effect of the arts up'


mankind. in our opinion applies more fore
bly, to this species of social intercourse:
~ --"ingenuas di dicisSe .fdctiliter art'


Emuiiu mores, nee Sinet esse feros"


One of the Expresses of Russia, was ful


sensible Of the efficacy of this mode OF civ
~ izing her subjects. who were not little


want of some reformation, as we may lea


from the following passage from the wor


of a writer whom we have already noticed


"Catharine Alexawna (says lord Kaime


promoted assemblies of men and women


means to polish the manners OF her su


ects. And in order to preserve decency


such assemblies, she published body


regulations, OF which the following are


specimen Ladies who play at forfeiture
questions, and commands, shall not be mol


nor riotus. No gentleman must attempt


force q kiss nor strike WON all IN the


scmbly. under pain ofeXclnsinn. Ladies


not to get drunk upon any pretext whate


err; nor gentlemen before nine"


-.

full articles.headline:
Fo, the IYilmingto'iic1

LINES,
full articles.article:
On the death Of a little Girl
Swee, ylsltnntl art thou forever fed
From this abode of earthly ills below
BY some ETHEREAL spirit led
Far from this world Of misery End %o;
tender plant in yon bright realm to grow,
And beam refulgent through eternal day,
And with chcrubic gratitude bestow
Thy infant meed' There, with unweared lay.
Praising thy Con who cali'd the hence away!
Dear child!-Methinks thy infant spirit there,
unstained by guile, must taste the purest JOY;
Freed from the varied ills Of earthly care,
Thy bliss is perfect, and without alloy,
Unminglcd by those griefs that oft annoy
0ur transient cup of pcace.--Yes, there above
Are pleasures which shall never cloy;
So far from mortal was thy great remove,
10 scenes unknown to aught but peace and


love!


Yes, little nc!-Transicnt was thy visit here,
Short was the Joy thy early being gave,
And eyes unused to sad affiction's tear,
Now weep in sorrow DER thy silent grave;
But weep in vain!-No earthly power could


save


Thy dying framc-and now. around thy tomb,
May these young Aowrctsi in their brightness


Wave,--


And as they wither, oh! may others bloom
Lmblcms, sweet innocent, of thy happy DOOM


BRANDYWINE MINSTREL.

full articles.headline:
From tile Ne,c- York Times.

LONDON.
full articles.article:
LONDON.


The first notice we have of London as a
place of commercial Importance, occurs in
the annals of Tacitus, who speaks of it as
the mobile emhorium of his time; the great
resort Of merchants, and famous for its trade
and intercourse, though not a colony"


".Abous the year 88. London, which APP
pears to have been almost totally destroyed
and dcpopulated by the Danes, was restored,
and more strongly fortified by Alfred, and
soon after iled with inhabitants who had
been driven into exile, or kept in captivity
by the Danes"


"In the year 1856, mandatory OF the
finer sort of glasses was established IN
Crutched Friars; and the fine flint glass, lit-
tie inferior to that of Venice, was at the
same time made at the Savoy. Seven years
afterwards. a manufacture OF knives was
established by Thomas Matthews. OF Fleet
Bridge"


"The whole number of merchants in Lon
don, at the beginning of Queen Elizabeths
reign, viz. Ammo Domini 1861, were in all on
ly 327"


"In the year 1859, Morgan Hubbel,horne.
a dyer, was sent into Persia, at the expense
of the city of London, to learn the art OF dy-
ing there, and Of making carpets
"In the year 1860, the Queen was pre-
sented with a pair of knit silk stockings for
new years gift, by her silk-woman, and
from that time Elizabeth entirely left off
the wearing of cloth hose for you will un-
derstand, says the historian, that King Henry
VII. did wear only cloth hose, or hose cut
of ell broad taffety."


an 1864. the use of coaches was intro
auct, by Dutchman, named Wilim Boonen,
who became the Queens coachman, and be-
fore many years, divers great ladies made
them coaches and rode in them up and down
the counties.


Shortly before that period, the knowledge
and wear of lawns and cambrics was intro
duced by the Dutch merchants, who retaileo
those articles in ellis, yards, &c, "for there


was not one shopkeeper amongst forty, Whe
burst buy zvhoie f!ece."


about the fifth OF sixth, of Elizabeth


the manufacture of pins was introduced


and in her eighth year, the making of needles


was Fl rst taught"


"About the fifth or sixth of Elizabeth, tn,
making Of earthcn furnaces, earthen .fei


hotfse, and earthen ovens, transportable


was first taught in London, without Moor


wac, by Richard Dyer, an Englshman, who


brought the art from Spain"


"yVoman's masks, muffs, fans, bodkins
and periwigs, were introduced from France
about the time Of the massacre in Paris


Ammo 1872; and in the year 1877, pocke
watches were first brought into London iron
|, Nuremberg. in Germany, where they ar


thought to have been invented"
Harrison, in his description of Britain,
first printed in 1877, speaking of the forests
remarks, "that an infinite deal of wood hat
| - fe,u nj


| dare affirm" he continues, in a tone ofpre
science. "that if woods do so SO fast to de


cay, in the next one hundred years, a


they have done, or as they do in this, it i
to be feared, that sea coal will be good mer
chandse, even in the very city OF London.


In 1915. two hundred sail were employs
in bringing coal to the metropolis.
, "The printing o. hrices current was frs
.. adopted by John Day, citzcn and sworn
broker of London. in 1884,"
!, The banking business commenced in l64a
as appears from very rare and curiou
pamphlet, entitled "The mysteries OF tn
, new fashioned goldsmiths. or bankers, dis
covered;" and in which It'll stated, that tn
merchants and traders of London, no longe
daring to confde, as before, in the integrit.
and care Of their apprentices and clerks, VIII
, frequently left their masters to go into tn
army, began first at this period to lodge thei
cash in the hands Of goldsmiths, whom the


also commissioned both to receive and pa
tor them. The goldsmiths quickly percei'
4 ing the great advantages that might be de
. rived from disposable capital, soon bega
to allow regular interest on all sums depos
9 tied.


t In the same year also, the use OF collie
] was introduced into London, by Turks
n merchant, who brought home with aim,
e servant. Ragusn Greek, sy whom the mar
+ ner OF roasting and making coffee was tir'
5 made known.


d In the year 1870. the wear of India A14siin
c was first introduced into London, and SOC
e became prevalent. In this year, also, IN
: Hudson Bay Comtany was incorporate
n with very enlarged powers, and the man.
e facture Of fine glass was brought to pcrte'
g tion, through the encouragement given 3

full articles.headline: LOVES LANGUAGE.
full articles.article:
There's a language that's mute, there's a silence


that speaks,


There is something that cannot be told.
These are words that can only he read in the


checks,


And thoughts but the eye can unfold.
There's look so expressive SO kind,
So conscious so quick to impart,
Though DUN, in an instant it speaks ont the


mind,


And strikes in an instant the heart.
This eloquent silence, this converse Of soul,
In vain we attempt to suppress;
More prompt it appears from the wish 70 control,
More apt the fond truth to express.
And oh the delights in the features that shine,
The raptures the bosom that melt,
When best with each other this converse divine
Is smutually spoken and felt.

full articles.headline: MY UNCLE's WEDDING.
full articles.article:
MY UNCLE's WEDDING.


NV uncle was q man of other years: that is,
his habits of acting and thinking were all formed
in the old school. He lived twenty years with
ON old fashioned wife; and as they had been born
and brought up together, they got along very
well, and were as hearty, thriving, happy cou-
lie, as any that are to be found to this day IN
Annandae. But the good woman died at last;
and my uncle could not endure a life of single
blessedncss, as some callit; it was very wretch-
edness, to him. SO he married new wife, with
new notions, new fashions, and all the ct ceteras
of the modern school. He thought he did We
ry wise thing. And he tapped me on the shoul-
der, lust as we were setting down to the wed.
ding supper, eBob," said he, in half whisper,
"get married.; there is nothing like it" "Cer.
tanly, SIR" said I, for reverenced his COUNSEL
"but it you please I'll stand by ana look ou'
little longer" 49,,
| When the hustle and noise was over little,
went down to the Dale to spend the summer
with my uncle. The good dame had begun the
work of reformaton cunning as fox, she mad
broke ground gently at first. There was rich
new mirror, hung low in the parlour; bold en-
croachment, for the old gentlemen used always
to hold that looking glasses were only made to
shave by, and that nobody who don't wear
beard ever ought to look in one; accordingly his
own glass had hung chin high for quarter OF
century, and not one ofhis own children had ev-
er seen its own face until they knew the use OF


razor.


One after another of the old articles Of furni.


ture were displaced, and new carpets, chairs, Ia


bles, &C. &c. introduced by my good aunt; and


whenever her spouse evnced the slightest dis


position to be angry, she gave him geod natur-


cd chuck under the chin, and assured the dear
fellow that good wife was always mistress OF
her house and that she was determined to be


good wife and rule the roast in her own domi-


Gil I,esides; she taught my uncle that his hand.


some fortune entitled him to look little above


his neighbors; to claim that quality which should,


as much as possible, exclude the idea OF equall-
ity, vulgar doctrine that had long been Preva-


lent in the Dale. :.


NV good uncle Yielded inch after inch to his


worthy spouse, until the old house was fitted up
in great style, and a common farmer would haro-


" know where to set down his 6 eat clumsy foot
in it. She obtained over him wonderful ascen-
dency some how; for he got to be as doc'e as
lamb. Sometimes, it is true, he locked sorrow.


full, and sighed deeply, and took his broad
brimmed hat and cane, and trudged over the
; fields to neighbor Hodges to sit and smoke his
S nine again in an old oaken chair by the great


chimney-place, and when there, he seemed 10th
to go back again; but he loved peace, and always
r went home at tea time 49,


NV aunt was woman of talent. She did one
. thing at time she was to be successful in
, whatever she undertook, for she bent all her


mind to the single object. 1t is this singleness


of purpose that removes mountains. She mad


now set her house rights, as she called it, and
= from sundry hints and preparations, l began ere
, long to surmse that she intended setting her old
man to rights next.


There was very little of the dandy about my
{ uncle He wore great brmmed hat upon his
:. hale round hcad-a shad-bellied coat of greasy


green, with dark ivory buttons; q vest of genu-
IL ,y, p,I tnaVNr .ttNfrsg
] velvet small clothes, buckles, and very large
d Shoes and made very portly, venerable appear
: ance in the sun. Beside, he used spectacles and
: tobacco, and trod fiat upon his feet when he
S walked


S Nv aunt began her second campaign. She
. bought him wig and quizzing-glass, declaring
y that he looked about fifty years too old tor
d her in his old fashions-and she got them


on too. The old man little testy, but she
:, took him by the arm and brought his bald pate
: and spectacles before the mirror. At any rate


this was the argument she used. His tobacco
box went next NV uncle scolded-Iny aunt
i, = r,asonei-and she beat him in the argument
- though he argued that tobacco was necessary to


preserve his teeth, but she sent tor dentist,
. and had them plugged and scoured' TIL he tarly
- - cried for mercy, and assured .'ie ueht'st eiey
- would last forever.


Y Rut nv uncle's troubles did not end here
o The next time his good lady went to town she
e bought him new suit of bright blue CLOTH
il rhe coat and vest would not meet around him

TIE SUNNY SPRING,
full articles.article:
TIE SUNNY SPRING,
The sunny Spring is breathing now,
A mellow richness fills the air,
rho bjue birds perch on every bough,
And early buds are swelling there,
tJn-while the balmy dews distl


Their pearl drops on the bended thorh,
Away-on yonder rounded hiil


Wen meet the sweet unclouded moTn---
Unclouded-in the wide domain


Offancy, there is not a scene
Richer and lovelier than the reign
Of Spring and her gay world OF green
No vision purer than that blue


Broad sky, begirt with starry gems,
Just fading far from mortal view,


like fancy's visioncd diadems.
From burning through the voiceless night,
And lst'ning to the skyward song,
Drinking each others balmy light,


And holding still communion long
Go they at morn's first oricn; beam,
To some unknown mysterious cline,
With records Of each sinful dream


That stained the shaded brow Of time
But snlcss nature smiled abroad,


Through lofty Wales and winding rllls;
And the peac e-speaking voice of God,
Gladdcns the valleys and the hills
Nature in harmony speaks out


The bursting rapture which she feels.
And fragrant odours breathe about
Where'er the golden day beam steals.
And was there not human voice


To swell the song that choir began
No-graseful nature may rejoice,


And praise-but not ungrateiul man,
